entirely by a human.', 'document_classification': 'HUMAN_ONLY', 'version': '2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'Terry Stackhouse is a weekend anchor and reporter with WMTW. He joined News 8 in May of 2020. He’s been reporting for nearly a decade, beginning in Bangor and continuing his career in Albany, New York before returning to the Pine Tree State. Stackhouse is a fellow of the First Amendment Coalition, participating in the organization’s 2020 institute with a focus on utilizing government records to strengthen reporting. He has produced data driven stories related to mental health, addiction, COVID-19 hospitalizations and Medicare. Immigration and refugee resettlement is of particular interest to Stackhouse. He has published stories highlighting the experiences of new Mainers from countries including Afghanistan, Iran, Iraq and Somalia. Stackhouse has researched barriers to refugee resettlements and reported on efforts to raise the United State’s annual refugee admissions cap. Stackhouse extensively covered the Black Lives Matter movement, reporting live during demonstrations in Portland and Lewiston. He has shared the experiences of participants and leaders in local efforts to advance social justice. Through reporting in WMTW News 8’s Project Community series, Stackhouse has sought to elevate the voices of Mainers seeking to strengthen our state by celebrating diversity. Since childhood, Stackhouse has had a passion for storytelling. At age 16, he started working for his hometown public access TV station in Wolfeboro, New Hampshire, broadcasting high school sports and covering local public affairs. He attended Emerson College and graduated in 2012 with a degree in broadcast journalism. Highlights of his early pursuits in reporting include coverage of the 2007 Major League Baseball All Star Game in San Francisco, CA and the 2010 Academy Awards in Los Angeles, CA. Stackhouse lives in Topsham with his wife, daughters and their dog Belle. Terry enjoys running and hiking on trails in Sagadahoc County, taking in Sea Dogs games, shopping at the Freeport outlets and L.L. Bean and finding new areas to explore in our state. Hearst Television participates in various affiliate marketing programs, which means we may get paid commissions on editorially chosen products purchased through our links to retailer sites.'}]

'2025-01-09-base', 'language': 'en', 'pageNumber': 0, 'inputText': 'Currently in Bangor STATEWIDE - The fervor for high school football is alive and well, but number are down. In the past year alone, schools around the state have had to call their own audible, just to get back on the field. 8-man football looks to be here to say. “The LTC was a good league, and it may, Dover and us may end up in it,” said Bucksport football head coach Joel Sankey. The state of the Little Ten Conference and Maine high school football begins far outside the gridiron. It’s a sport that has mirrored the framework of the communities in which it’s played. “I remember going to Stearns the first time, and I was just blown away with Stearns. The community was alive, you drive by those three mills that were going 24 hours a day, you’d go to their homes games there’d be 1500 people at their home games, it was exciting. There were 700 kids at that school…now look at it,” Sankey said. Cities throughout the state have been forced to adjust to a loss of industry, and an aging demographic shuttering school enrollment and dropping participation in sports. The once great Little Ten Conference is down to just two teams playing 11-man football; Dover-Foxcroft and Bucksport. “We have roughly 35, 34, 35 kids. Years ago when I first started here, we could have a freshman team with somewhere between 20 and 24 kids," Sankey said. Rich football tradition has powered the Golden Bucks to multiple northern Maine titles and state championships over the years, but history doesn’t fill out a uniform, and across Maine, storied programs have had little choice but to make an adjustment. “Schools like Cheverus, which used to be a powerhouse down in the Portland area, playing 8-man football--you just shake your head. That’s a private catholic school,” Sankey said. Billed as an alternative for teams with low numbers, 8-man football was introduced to Maine starting in 2019, adding to the nearly 40 states across the country that had already downsized. 10 teams statewide took part in the pilot program, and Ellsworth became the first Little Ten School to make the switch. "It was a great experience and the kids loved it, and the bottom line is it’s football. It’s no different than 11-man football except there’s three less guys on the team,” said Duane Crawford, former Ellsworth football head coach who led the Eagles into the 8-man era. The decision was met with skepticism from communities, parents and players, even when positioned as a lifeline for dwindling programs. “I think the overall perception from the majority of the football community was that 8-man football was not football,” Crawford said. That fall, Tug White Field was brought in five yards on either side, and two lineman and a skill player were removed from the equation. Turns out? It’s still football after all. “I didn’t really like it at first. I thought I was kind of a dumb idea, but I like it now because we always had small teams. This is the biggest team I’ve ever played on, 23 kids or whatever, but it’s nice because when you only have a 15-man team, it’s a small sideline when you look over,” said Jack Johnston, junior fullback for Ellsworth. This season, nearly three times as many teams have made the switch, binging the total number of 8-man programs to 25, enough for both Large school and Small school classes with two divisions each. It’s a stark change after going all of 2020 without tackle football. “I think the coaches had time to look at it, they saw the product on the field from 2019 and said this is a pretty good choice for us, especially since we’re seeing numbers decline for whatever the reason may be,” Crawford said. The pivot may read as a kiss of death to some, or the end of an era for Maine high school football, but for others, 8-man is a saving grace--an audible that breathes fresh life into football programs from Kittery to Houlton. “It’s different, and I get that, and a lot of times different isn’t always accepted, but again I have to stress that 8-man has saved football in a lot of communities in the state of Maine,” said Fred Lower, Char of the MPA Football Committee. “It stays alive, let’s put it that way. Without 8-man football, there would be programs that wouldn’t be around," Sankey said.
